Introduction

1 A King and Two Foxes: Middle Dutch Literature on European Crossroads Geert H.M. Claassens

3 Die Rose by Heinric of Brussels, the Brabantine Version of the Old French Romance of the Rose Anne Reynders

7 Multatuli – His Work Through the World Jaap Grave

9 Louis Couperus in Translation Ruud Veen

10 Dutch Literature and the Global System of Indentured Labour, 1900–1940 Saskia Pieterse

11 Towards a History of Russian Translations of Dutch Literature: Herman Heijermans and His Play The Good Hope in Russia Irina Michajlova and Sergei Tcherkasski

12 Rescuing Something Fine: Huizinga’s Herfsttij der Middeleeuwen (The Waning of the Middle Ages) as World Literature Elke Brems and Orsolya Réthelyi

13 ‘Glimpses of a poetic genius’: Paul van Ostaijen (1896–1928) and World Literature Geert Buelens

14 Dutch Interbellum Poetry and/as World Literature Theo D’haen

15 Reinventing the Modernist Novel: Louis Paul Boon and Hugo Claus Kris Humbeeck

16 Small Amsterdam and the World Beyond: The Case of the Magazine Barbarber Bart Vervaeck and Dirk de Geest

17 Post-war Dutch Fiction Hans Bertens

18 Expansions Without Affect; Identities Without Globality: Global Novels in Dutch from an Agonistic Perspective Hans Demeyer

19 Orpheus in the Trenches: Modes of Translation in Stefan Hertmans’ War and Turpentine Frank Albers

20 At the Edge of the World and Other Stories: Dutch-Australian Emigration Literature, c. 1945–1990 Ton van Kalmthout
